articles.headline: Rashida Tlaib’s Expletive-Laden Cry to Impeach Trump Upends Democrats’ Talking Points
articles.snippet: Republicans pounced at the Michigan congresswoman’s remarks to paint the majority as a power-hungry bloc intent on destroying the Trump presidency.
articles.abstract: Republicans pounced at the Michigan congresswoman’s remarks to paint the majority as a power-hungry bloc intent on destroying the Trump presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Impeachment was always going to hang heavily over a divided Washington. But it took little more than 24 hours this week for a freshman House Democrat’s exuberant, expletive-laden impeachment promise to upend the bonhomie of a new Congress and prompt President Trump, by his own telling, to ask the newly elected speaker if Democrats planned to impeach him.

articles.headline: In Price and Value, Chinese Phone Makers Outpace Apple in Much of the World
articles.snippet: The tech giant’s recent warning about disappointing iPhone sales in China obscured the fact that it is also losing out to Chinese brands in places like France, Germany, India and Southeast Asia.
articles.abstract: The tech giant’s recent warning about disappointing iPhone sales in China obscured the fact that it is also losing out to Chinese brands in places like France, Germany, India and Southeast Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — To most Americans, the names are unfamiliar, maybe a little hard to pronounce: Huawei, Xiaomi, Oppo, Vivo.

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Should Be More Generous With Federal Workers.
articles.snippet: The scandal-plagued bank could go a long way to help federal employees who aren’t being paid during the shutdown. Why hasn’t it done more?
articles.abstract: The scandal-plagued bank could go a long way to help federal employees who aren’t being paid during the shutdown. Why hasn’t it done more?
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo says it wants to make things right with the American public. After years of cheating its customers, the bank has a golden opportunity to make good on its promises.

articles.headline: Matteo Salvini Likes Nutella and Kittens. It’s All Part of a Social Media Strategy.
articles.snippet: The online feed of Italy’s most powerful politician is not about product placement, but a studied way to sell his common-man brand in an anti-elite era.
articles.abstract: The online feed of Italy’s most powerful politician is not about product placement, but a studied way to sell his common-man brand in an anti-elite era.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Matteo Salvini likes spreading Nutella on his morning bread. He winds down with a bowl of Barilla pasta and a glass of Barolo wine. He heeds the words of wisdom inside the wrappers of Perugina Bacio chocolates. He drinks Moretti beer.

articles.headline: The Price of Trump’s Migrant Deterrence Strategy: New Chaos on the Border
articles.snippet: A crisis is emerging at migrant shelters as the Trump administration focuses, as one official put it, on “how can we deter, rather than how can we handle.”
articles.abstract: A crisis is emerging at migrant shelters as the Trump administration focuses, as one official put it, on “how can we deter, rather than how can we handle.”
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — At a migrant shelter near the Mexican border, three girls from Guatemala — sisters aged 10, 9 and 6 — coughed and sniffled. One of them clung to both a teddy bear and a large bottle of Pedialyte, to soothe her dehydration and flu.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Caitlin Dickerson and Paulina Villegas

articles.headline: As Fires Ravaged California, Utilities Lobbied Lawmakers for Protection
articles.snippet: Facing billions of dollars in damages, PG&E and other utilities want legislators to let them pass on the cost to homeowners through higher electricity rates.
articles.abstract: Facing billions of dollars in damages, PG&E and other utilities want legislators to let them pass on the cost to homeowners through higher electricity rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As California’s deadliest wildfire was consuming the town of Paradise in November, some of the state’s top power company officials and a dozen legislators were at an annual retreat at the Fairmont Kea Lani resort on Maui. In the course of four days, they discussed wildfires — and how much responsibility the utilities deserve for the devastation, if any.

articles.headline: Apple’s Biggest Problem? My Mom
articles.snippet: The most consequential hit to the bottom line may be from people, including longtime fans, who are holding on to their phones longer.
articles.abstract: The most consequential hit to the bottom line may be from people, including longtime fans, who are holding on to their phones longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Apple lost more than $75 billion in market value this past week after a surprise announcement that it is expecting lower iPhone sales than originally projected, the company put most of the blame for its troubles on China, where a slowing economy and the trade war with the United States have hurt sales.

articles.headline: ‘There’s a Real Tension.’ Democrats Puzzle Over Whether a Woman Will Beat Trump
articles.snippet: The presence of multiple female entries in the race could help Democrats move past a set of political expectations for women largely defined by Hillary Clinton.
articles.abstract: The presence of multiple female entries in the race could help Democrats move past a set of political expectations for women largely defined by Hillary Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joyce Cusack would love to see a woman as president in her lifetime. But she is not sure it should happen in 2020.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Susan Chira

articles.headline: After a Rocky 2018, Populism Is Down but Far From Out in the West
articles.snippet: Hard-line leaders and parties are responding to setbacks by revitalizing a sense of crisis and stripping down their message to its core: a skepticism toward liberal ideals.
articles.abstract: Hard-line leaders and parties are responding to setbacks by revitalizing a sense of crisis and stripping down their message to its core: a skepticism toward liberal ideals.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — President Trump’s push for a border wall hints at a problem that populist leaders are facing across the Western world.

articles.headline: How the Border Wall Is Boxing Trump In
articles.snippet: What started out as a memory trick for an undisciplined candidate has become the central priority of the Trump presidency, even as some immigration hard-liners do not view it as a top goal.
articles.abstract: What started out as a memory trick for an undisciplined candidate has become the central priority of the Trump presidency, even as some immigration hard-liners do not view it as a top goal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before it became the chief sticking point in a government shutdown drama that threatens to consume his presidency at a critical moment, President Trump’s promise to build a wall on the southwestern border was a memory trick for an undisciplined candidate.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Peter Baker

articles.headline: As Big Retailers Seek to Cut Their Tax Bills, Towns Bear the Brunt
articles.snippet: If Walmart, Lowe’s and other companies win their property tax appeals, homeowners and small businesses will have to pay more or live with smaller town budgets.
articles.abstract: If Walmart, Lowe’s and other companies win their property tax appeals, homeowners and small businesses will have to pay more or live with smaller town budgets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAUWATOSA, Wis. — With astonishing range and rapidity, big-box retailers and corporate giants are using an aggressive legal tactic to shrink their property tax bills, a strategy that is costing local governments and school districts around the country hundreds of millions of dollars in lost revenue.

articles.headline: Trump Has Promised to Bring Jobs Back. His Tariffs Threaten to Send Them Away.
articles.snippet: American factories complain that President Trump’s tariffs are hurting profits in the industrial heartland.
articles.abstract: American factories complain that President Trump’s tariffs are hurting profits in the industrial heartland.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLAND, Mich. — Plants in every direction shut down and moved their operations to Mexico, succumbing to the relentless pressure to cut costs in an age of globalization. Not EBW Electronics. As the decades passed, the family-owned business stayed put on the eastern edge of Lake Michigan, churning out lights for the auto industry.

articles.headline: A Quiet Revolution: More Women Seek Divorces in Conservative West Africa
articles.snippet: Frustrated by their husbands’ inability to earn a living, and in a society where basic views on relationships have changed, women are asserting more control over their marriages.
articles.abstract: Frustrated by their husbands’ inability to earn a living, and in a society where basic views on relationships have changed, women are asserting more control over their marriages.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARADI, Niger — He didn’t hit her. He didn’t yell. He didn’t cheat, as far as she knows. It was just that, less than two years into their marriage, Zalika Amadou’s husband had changed. He’d become far too neglectful and indifferent for a young woman who expected, well, more.

articles.headline: Bolton Puts Conditions on Syria Withdrawal, Suggesting a Delay of Months or Years
articles.snippet: John R. Bolton, the national security adviser, said troops would remain until the Islamic State was completely defeated and Turkey guaranteed it would not strike Kurdish forces.
articles.abstract: John R. Bolton, the national security adviser, said troops would remain until the Islamic State was completely defeated and Turkey guaranteed it would not strike Kurdish forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s national security adviser, John R. Bolton, rolled back on Sunday Mr. Trump’s decision to rapidly withdraw from Syria, laying out conditions for a pullout that could leave American forces there for months or even years.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Noah Weiland and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Who Wants a Market Downturn? These Investors Actually Do
articles.snippet: Some venture capitalists are rooting for a market dip to calm Silicon Valley’s overheated start-up scene.
articles.abstract: Some venture capitalists are rooting for a market dip to calm Silicon Valley’s overheated start-up scene.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Vini Letteri, a managing director at KKR who invests in tech companies, had a slow 2018.

articles.headline: Netflix’s Bow to Saudi Censors Comes at a Cost to Free Speech
articles.snippet: The decision to remove an episode from its service in Saudi Arabia raises questions of whether entertainment giants will fight for values like free expression.
articles.abstract: The decision to remove an episode from its service in Saudi Arabia raises questions of whether entertainment giants will fight for values like free expression.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under Article 6, Paragraph 1 of Saudi Arabia’s Anti-Cyber Crime Law, the following is punishable by up to five years in prison: “Production, preparation, transmission, or storage of material impinging on public order, religious values, public morals, and privacy, through the information network or computers.”

articles.headline: Arrest in Jazmine Barnes’s Killing Allays Hate-Crime Fears
articles.snippet: The suspect the Houston authorities charged with capital murder on Sunday in the shooting death of a 7-year-old black girl is not the white man initially described by witnesses.
articles.abstract: The suspect the Houston authorities charged with capital murder on Sunday in the shooting death of a 7-year-old black girl is not the white man initially described by witnesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — It was a face that haunted many people in the nation’s fourth-largest city: The police sketch of the unshaven white man who witnesses and the authorities said had opened fire on a black family in a car the day before New Year’s Eve.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Sarah Mervosh and Mihir Zaveri

articles.headline: Migrants’ Despair Is Growing at U.S. Border. So Are Smugglers’ Profits.
articles.snippet: Only a handful of asylum seekers are let across the border each day. Many are now weighing the risks of hiring “polleros” to sneak them in.
articles.abstract: Only a handful of asylum seekers are let across the border each day. Many are now weighing the risks of hiring “polleros” to sneak them in.
articles.lead_paragraph: REYNOSA, Mexico — As the human smugglers stalk the bus stations, migrant shelters and twisting streets of this Mexican border town, they have no trouble collecting clients like Julian Escobar Moreno.

articles.headline: Democrats Faked Online Push to Outlaw Alcohol in Alabama Race
articles.snippet: A prohibitionist campaign appeared to be led by supporters of the Republican Senate candidate in 2017. But it was created by progressives — the second such secret effort to be unmasked.
articles.abstract: A prohibitionist campaign appeared to be led by supporters of the Republican Senate candidate in 2017. But it was created by progressives — the second such secret effort to be unmasked.
articles.lead_paragraph: The “Dry Alabama” Facebook page, illustrated with stark images of car wrecks and videos of families ruined by drink, had a blunt message: Alcohol is the devil’s work, and the state should ban it entirely.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Alan Blinder
